docs.lead_paragraph: In a push to lock down votes, Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, is pulling together a last-minute package of changes to his health care legislation aimed at addressing the chief concern among his fellow Democrats: that health insurance be made as affordable as possible for moderate-income Americans.

headline.main: Baucus Weighing Changes to Make Insurance More Affordable

docs.abstract: Senator Baucus is pulling together a last-minute package of changes to his health care legislation, aimed at his fellow Democrats who want insurance be made as affordable as possible for moderate-income Americans.
docs.snippet: Senator Baucus is pulling together a last-minute package of changes to his health care legislation, aimed at his fellow Democrats who want insurance be made as affordable as possible for moderate-income Americans.

docs.lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I posted an email from a young woman named Emmie who was 23 years old, single, about to enter a competitive graduate school program, and unexpectedly pregnant. She was looking for advice - should she terminate the pregnancy, place the baby for adoption, or raise the child herself? More than 1,000 of you wrote first with advice and counsel; then, when she decided to have an abortion, hundreds more wrote expressing either sympathy or anger.
docs.abstract: A young woman who finds herself pregnant is looking for advice on things like how to tell her family, and what to do about health insurance.
docs.snippet: A young woman who finds herself pregnant is looking for advice on things like how to tell her family, and what to do about health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: The president of the United States was on the line. And what he wanted was the commitment of a vote in favor of the health care legislation now under consideration in the Senate Finance Committee.

headline.main: An Obama Phone Call, But Senator Rockefeller Makes No Commitments

docs.abstract: A call from the president may not placate Senator Rockefeller.
docs.snippet: A call from the president may not placate Senator Rockefeller.

docs.lead_paragraph: It may feel endless, but the health care debate in many ways is just getting started - the various bills are nearly ready, and full debate in the House and Senate lies just ahead. And yet, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, 6 out of 10 people in the United States are confused about the plans to overhaul the health system.

headline.main: Still Confused? A Refresher on the Basics of the Health Debate

docs.abstract: Still confused about the health care debate? Review these basic concepts, and you might be in a better position to argue your position -- or form an opinion.
docs.snippet: Still confused about the health care debate? Review these basic concepts, and you might be in a better position to argue your position -- or form an opinion.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday, The Agenda took a closer look at the big job losses that did not result from San Francisco's play-or-pay mandate. But there's another fear that critics of a mandate sometimes voice: that many businesses will simply drop health insurance because it is cheaper to pay the tax.

headline.main: Will Health Care Reform Encourage Small Businesses to Drop Health Coverage?

docs.abstract: Or is offering health insurance more than just a dollars-and-cents calculation for most employers?
docs.snippet: Or is offering health insurance more than just a dollars-and-cents calculation for most employers?

docs.lead_paragraph: When Senators Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Finance Committee, and Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, voted against a government-run insurance plan on Tuesday, they made themselves targets of liberal activists who are determined to see a public option become part of a health care overhaul.

headline.main: Liberal Groups Raise Funds Off Baucus, Snowe Votes

docs.abstract: Liberal activists are raising money for an ad campaign in hopes of changing the two senators' minds on the public option.
docs.snippet: Liberal activists are raising money for an ad campaign in hopes of changing the two senators' minds on the public option.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama and his top commander in Afghanistan, Gen. Stanley McChrystal, will come face-to-face Wednesday -- via secure video -- as the general makes his case for providing more troops for the eight-year-old conflict.
docs.abstract: The president continues deliberations over his Afghanistan strategy, meeting via video with his commander on the ground there.
docs.snippet: The president continues deliberations over his Afghanistan strategy, meeting via video with his commander on the ground there.

headline.print_headline: Medicare, Fear and the Health Debate

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress is preparing to extend the National Flood Insurance Program, despite warnings that the program lacks adequate controls and may be shifting too much money to the insurance industry.

headline.seo: Congress Prepares to Extend Flood Insurance Plan
headline.main: Criticism Is Mounting Over Flood Premiums
headline.print_headline: Criticism Is Mounting Over Flood Premiums

docs.snippet: Congress is preparing to extend the National Flood Insurance Program, despite warnings that the program lacks adequate controls and may be shifting too much money to the insurance industry.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lobbyists for unions and big business are staunchly opposed to a tax on generous health insurance plans, but their motives are questionable.

headline.main: How a Tax Can Cut Health Costs
